meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry I was muted. It's been a couple of minutes, I think we're going to start the discussion. Just a couple of ideas/tips. meeting_annotations.speaker: Charles McCrory
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm happy to start. One of the things, especially going beyond CO2, one of the things obviously is nitrogen transformation, nitrogen to ammonia or just ammonia, sustainable ammonia synthesis in general. I think the real thing is doing that as low temperature ammonia synthesis. That could be direct electrochemical, but probably more practical is to do a low temperature hydrogenation for distributed ammonia because the issue right now is when you do elevated temperatures, you have to do elevated pressures of H2 to overcome the thermodynamic barriers of increasing the temperature to go with the kinetic barrier of nitrogen-nitrogen bond cleavage. So if you can do low temperature, if you can break that nitrogen-nitrogen bond kinetically at lower temperatures, then you don't need as much hydrogen pumping in. You don't need the pressures of hydrogen which allows you to use electrolytic hydrogen from solar hydrogen. Or you could do direct electrochemical, although I think that's very very hard to outcompete hydrogen evolution for electrochemical ammonia.
meeting_annotations.other: He effectively kicks off the scientific discussion by volunteering and presenting a well-defined problem.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marta Hatzell
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I'll jump in there too and say in addition to ammonia, so we're going through the, I think we're all touching on all the different nitrogen transformations, but looking at direct nitrogen oxidation so you can skip the nitrogen to ammonia, ammonia to NOx, doing direct nitrogen oxidation has not been demonstrated from my perspective. It has been demonstrated in papers but I would say that that's still has not really been demonstrated. That would be a large energy savings instead of having to go through ammonia as an intermediate. With the question of the nitrogen also, I think that there's lots of questions on whether ammonia should be used as a fuel as well as a fertilizer. And I think that from a life cycle perspective, you're running into questions that mirror that with respect to ethanol. And so it may not be the end-all molecule. And so my main thing is talking about where we really do think ammonia should be used, kind of needs to be something that is defined in the literature. I'm hesitant to say that it's the end-all molecule for all applications, but that's starting to emerge as a topic. So I agree, nitrogen oxidation, I'm a big fan of that for sure.
